title: Why should a college education be free? - Quora

response.answer_text: Several reasons… Nothing is free. You have to take money to pay for this… whether in taxes or debt.Most people do not need a college education. Only about 20% of the population is employed in professions needing a college degree.It wasted four years of people’s lives. This is four years people could be working, or getting a trades diploma. That is four years of people not contributing to GDP, taxes, getting actual work experience, etc.It is a waste of resources. You now need colleges able to house 2–3x more students, more professors, buildings, etc. 80% of which won’t be used.It encourages colleges to just keep charging more and more. (As per student loans). If people had to actually pay for education, they wouldn’t be paying these $40k, $80k, or $100k a year prices. If the government is paying it… what is stopping a college from charging double?It reduces the quality of your education. If you fill all your seats because the government is paying for them… why try to be the best law school? You don’t have to compete for students.It encourages employers to ask for degrees for jobs which don’t need them. Need a janitor… fine… I want a four year degree. That will really hurt anyone not able to get a degree.It doesn’t direct the people into meaningful professions. Nothing stopping anyone from taking a major in basket weaving vs. engineering. It isn’t like you have to convince a bank that you’ll be able to pay them back with a basket weaving degree.It gives the government more control over your life and that of your children. Besides the massively skewed political make up of universities, terrible freedom of thought, etc. it means young people are denied all sorts of opportunities — military, working, starting businesses, travelling, etc. — which give real work experience, fill vital roles, give you a broader perspective on the country/world, etc., etc.It is going to make degrees worthless. If you have three times as many people with engineering degrees… its kind of hard to imagine that the quality of engineers didn’t go down.Almost certain that colleges and employers will then start putting things in place to weed out the mass of degree holders — hire foreign degrees, only hire the top third of any graduating class, cut the salary of engineers dramatically, run them through their own tests, etc.etc.

You are asking for Professors to teach for free… how would they eat? Why should everybody pay for college too? Might as well extend high school at that point. Instead, make taxpayer dollar go further by making high school worthy of an accomplishment. Not the beginning of more training… for some it just is, but in today’s culture we are educated fools. Doctors don’t do surgery for free typically. There is pro bono and volunteering in third world’s but the volunteers are beyond human. If we take this to it’s extreme why shouldn’t every service be free? Why not tax everyone at 100%? No one owns the fruits of their labor… and let the government decide what you drive, eat, where you live. No snacks because you are on a government mandated diet. It sounds too controlling and abusive to me. Someone would have to control the amount of resources a person gets… some people would take way more than others. Greed doesn’t go away. Also, if college were free, there would be one less benefit of going into the military. It totally ruins earning something. Then, it also ruins the degree value and we are stuck with a modern high school diploma that took an extra 4 years. The only reason I would want college to be free is if I didn’t do anything to pay for it, and run a guilt trip about how it would feel to fall behind. You are not entitled to have a professor tell you about stuff, or a doctor to fix you (luckily they have an oath), it’s up to them. Money is a very good trade. It’s sort of I saved up and really want this. It feels better saving up and working towards a goal, than to be just given something… and when something works out unexpectedly you don’t get this attitude the world owes you something. It’s like the one friend who spends all his money on weed and gets jealous about the other friend who saved up for an Xbox. I’d like to be able to keep money and spend it on what I want. The weed guy did but just chose to get high, he smoked his Xbox. If you are actually disabled or something then it’d be different. Like a rare genetic disorder or PTSD. It’s sorta the cost of being a society. Not everybody and anybody. It’s like saying everyone should be able to get into the NFL.
